docs.lead_paragraph: Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey said yesterday that it was cutting its monthly premiums by up to 15 percent for 45,000 elderly and disabled people, as a result of additional reimbursements approved by Congress. The reduction, which began in the middle of the month, involves policies available to people eligible for Medicare who are at least 65 years old or disabled. The reduction comes to $8.33 a month, with resulting monthly premiums of $46.67 for the basic Medicare Blue plan and $81.67 for Medicare Blue Plus, which includes a prescription plan. Horizon, based in Newark, is New Jersey's largest health insurer, with 2.4 million people enrolled.

headline.main: Metro Business Briefing; CHEAPER HEALTH INSURANCE

docs.abstract: Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey says that it is cutting its monthly premiums by up to 15 percent for 45,000 people eligible for Medicare (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislative leaders from both political parties in Nassau County say a proposed labor contract that the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, has negotiated with county correction officers is unacceptable. Their stance has caused concern among union leaders who represent 1,050 officers who work at the county jail. And the dispute could spill over to other unions, as the county is currently trying to reach a contract with the police union.

headline.main: Nassau Lawmakers Oppose Jail Officers' Pact

docs.abstract: Legislative leaders from both political parties in Nassau County say proposed labor contract that County Executive Thomas S Gulotta has negotiated with county correction officers is unacceptable; proposal would increase salaries by 28.5 percent (M)
